items.title: Two National Guard members shot in Washington, D.C.
Ontario grocers could avoid taking beer and wine empties under new deal
items.summary_auto: Ontario grocers and the Beer Store have reached an agreement-in-principle on alcohol recycling that will allow the retailers to avoid collecting empties at their stores and gives a renewed role to the brewers, The Canadian Press has learned.

items.title: Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen answers your questions
items.summary_auto: Astronaut Jeremy Hansen took questions from across the country before he blasts off to space for the Artemis II mission, where he’ll become the first Canadian to fly around the moon.

items.title: How will Stranger Things’ final season end? Fans have many theories on that
items.summary_auto: Stranger Things fans will finally get some answers when Season 5 drops today — but that's not stopping them from speculating about who might die or how the show’s villains might be defeated. They say whether they’re right or wrong, it's fun to predict how the beloved series will come to a close.

items.title: Year after quadriplegic Quebec man chose assisted dying, advocates prepare class action
items.summary_auto: Advocates and the widow of a quadriplegic Quebec man are preparing to file a class-action lawsuit against the province after the 66-year-old requested medical assistance in dying following a hospital stay last year that left him with a severe bedsore.

items.title: Oilpatch drilling slows as oil and natural gas prices sink
items.summary_auto: Low oil and natural gas prices are taking a toll on the industry as drilling activity is falling in Western Canada and job losses are mounting.

items.title: Canada’s weather warning system has changed. Here’s how
items.summary_auto: Canada's weather warnings have changed to a new colour-coded, risk-tiered system implemented by Environment and Climate Change Canada. The three alert levels — yellow, orange and red — are based on the potential impacts of a weather event and the forecast confidence.

items.title: Critics worry about Liberal plan to fast-track high-speed rail
items.summary_auto: In an effort to halve the approval time for Canada’s new high-speed rail network, the Liberal government is streamlining how it expropriates land in a way that some say could compromise property rights and lead to costly mistakes.

items.title: Millions in funding for First Nations and Inuit policing left unspent, says budget watchdog
items.summary_auto: A report from the federal spending watchdog shows that although funding has increased for First Nations and Inuit policing services, spending for the programs hasn't caught up, while Indigenous communities say their police services are going underfunded.

items.title: New prosecutor won't pursue charges against Trump in Georgia election interference case
items.summary_auto: A judge on Wednesday dismissed the Georgia election interference case against U.S. President Donald Trump and others after the prosecutor who took over the case said he would not pursue the charges, ending the last effort to prosecute Trump for his efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss.

items.title: Shelter runs out of naloxone as B.C. community sees 80 drug overdoses in 24 hours
items.summary_auto: Erin Kapela, executive director of the Canadian Mental Health Association (CMHA) Cowichan Valley Branch, said an estimated 80 toxic drug poisonings were reported from Nov. 18 to 19 — but as of Nov. 25, no resulting fatalities had been confirmed.

items.title: More Canadians are missing non-mortgage debt payments, says Equifax
items.summary_auto: Equifax Canada says the number of consumers missing a non-mortgage debt payment in the third quarter rose compared with a year ago.

items.title: The best yet on ice and snow: Excitement builds 100 days out to Winter Paralympics in Italy
items.summary_auto: More than 600 athletes are expected to compete across 6 sports when the best Para athletes in the world descend on Italy in March.

items.title: 36 dead, 279 missing in Hong Kong highrise complex fire
Steve Witkoff to meet Russian officials again as leaked phone call rankles U.S. lawmakers
items.summary_auto: Donald Trump is sticking with longtime friend and special envoy for peace missions, Steve Witkoff, even as a report late Tuesday appeared to portray Witkoff as coaching an aide to Russian President Vladimir Putin on how to approach the U.S. president.

items.title: Experts warn the devil is in the details with Alberta's 'experiment' to expand private health care
items.summary_auto: Some health experts say they’re worried the new legislation designed to expand private health care in Alberta was not properly planned and is missing key protections for the public health system.

items.title: Townhome owners stuck footing $2M bill after stormwater system at new-build complex collapses
Woman at centre of Sask. triple homicide says she shot in self-defence
items.summary_auto: Madison Jimmy describes the events that led to her being charged with second-degree murder after a triple homicide on a farm near Turtleford, Sask.

items.title: Hong Kong highrise fire leaves at least 36 dead
items.summary_auto: Hong Kong's leader John Lee has said that 36 people were reported dead in the fire that spread through a dense highrise residential complex on Wednesday, and that another 279 people were reported missing.

items.title: Can you see Newfoundland from Cape Breton? Online photo sparks debate
items.summary_auto: An online photo has sparked a passionate debate about whether or not it's possible.

items.title: N.B. viola player tuning up for performance at Carnegie Hall
items.summary_auto: Earlier this year, Elsipogtog First Nation's Daniel Milliea placed third in an international talent competition. He's been invited to perform at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 20 alongside some of the best musicians from 10 countries.

items.title: Israel returns 15 more Palestinian bodies to Gaza as 1st phase of ceasefire nears end
items.summary_auto: Israel handed over the bodies of 15 Palestinians on Wednesday, a day after Hamas returned the remains of an Israeli hostage.

items.title: N.L. sea urchin fishery in jeopardy, says owner of one of the province's only plants
items.summary_auto: Newfoundland and Labrador's sea urchin fishery is on the verge of collapse, as the fish harvesters and divers are confined to certain overfished areas, says Jerry and Alisha Hodder, owners of one of the province's last urchin plants. They say DFO could fix the problem with the stroke of a pen.

items.title: Assaults on public transit have doubled in 8 major Canadian cities
Transit violence rising across Canada — in some cities by nearly 300%
items.summary_auto: A joint investigation by CBC News and the Investigative Journalism Foundation has found that transit violence in some of Canada's biggest municipalities remains well above pre-pandemic levels, despite recent decreases. It has roughly doubled over the past decade in eight major Canadian cities.

items.title: F-35 beat Gripen fighter jet 'by a mile' in 2021 Defence Department competition
items.summary_auto: The American-built F-35 fighter jet dominated its Swedish rival Gripen in terms of technical and military capabilities during a competition held by the Defence Department in 2021, according to data obtained by Radio-Canada.

items.title: Why invoking the notwithstanding clause no longer seems politically taboo
items.summary_auto: The notwithstanding clause allows for premiers or prime ministers to override rulings on legislation that judges have determined would violate sections of the Charter. But the use of the clause, once viewed by many as a political taboo, has become more frequent in recent years.

items.title: Will the Canada-Alberta 'Grand Bargain' oil pipeline deal lead to more emissions?
items.summary_auto: A historic oil pipeline deal between the federal and Alberta governments — set to be announced on Thursday — could lead to more production in the oilsands, cementing Canada’s position as one of the world’s largest fossil fuel producers while pushing its climate targets even further out of reach.

items.title: Carney to announce aid measures for steel and lumber sectors
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney will announce new aid measures Wednesday aimed at helping Canada's steel and lumber sectors.

items.title: B.C. teacher disciplined after talking to student on Grindr, engaging in sexual contact: regulator
items.summary_auto: A B.C. teacher will not be allowed to be certified for eight years after messaging a student on the Grindr dating app and engaging in sexual relations with them.

items.title: Jamaican bobsleigh team captures historic gold medal at Whistler competition
items.summary_auto: Nearly 40 years after the Jamaica bobsleigh team's first Winter Olympics inspired the film Cool Runnings, the team made history again last weekend when it captured its first ever gold medal at an international bobsleigh race.
